#F nk_Palik.dat
#C  This file has been created using nk_Palik.pro
#D  Tue Sep 18 14:09:29 2001
#C  This file belongs to the DABAX library. More information on
#C  DABAX can be found at:
#C http://www.esrf.fr/computing/scientific/dabax
#UIDL xnk
#UT Tables from the Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids, Palik & Bennet (Eds.)
#UD Tables from the Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids, Palik & Bennet (Eds.)
#UD 
#UD 
#UD This DABAX file contains all the tables from the Handbook of Optical Constants 
#UD of Solids, Volumes 1 and 2. The data was provided in diskettes by the
#UD editors and was converted to DABAX format.
#UD 
#UD In the following lines you can find information from the original
#UD diskette distribution. There is an extensive reference list with is 
#UD included in this DABAX file under the keyword #UREF
#UD 
#UD The coulums in this file change from one scan to other. The three firts
#UD lines contain the photon wavelength or related magnitudes (in eV,cm-1 
#UD and µm respectively) and the rest of the columns contains n [refraction
#UD index] and k, sometimes for several references, thus duplicating
#UD columns. Data not available in the tables have been completed with the
#UD value -0.0001 which should be read as "not available".
#UD 
#UD ---------------------- starts included documentation ---------------------
#UD 
#UD Tables from the Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids, Volumes 1 and 2.
#UD 
#UD  Edited by Edward D. Palik and Jean M. Bennett.
#UD 
#UD  (c) Copyright 1995 The Optical Society of America
#UD 
#UD Most of the tables on these diskettes have been newly formatted tomake data 
#UD import into spreadsheets or other programs easier.  Inseveral cases, new 
#UD data have been added that were not available at the time that the original 
#UD volumes were published.  Many of the data in the tables and references are from 
#UD HANDBOOKOF OPTICAL CONSTANTS OF SOLIDS (HOC) I and II edited by 
#UD Edward D.Palik Copyright (c) 1985, 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. reproducedby 
#UD permission of the publisher.
#UD 
#UD 
#UD      After HOCI was published in 1985, I received a few inquiries
#UD about putting the tables of n and k on floppy disks.  I had not
#UD asked the critiquers to supply me with such disks.  For HOCII
#UD published in 1991 I did ask the critiquers to put the n and k
#UD data on disks.  While I did supply a few scientists with disks of
#UD the tables in HOCII, they did not receive wide distribution.  
#UD      In 1993 I approached Frank Harris and Dr. Jean M. Bennett of
#UD the Optical Society of America and volunteered to re-edit all the
#UD tables in HOCI and HOCII into a more useful format for plotting
#UD and manipulating purposes.  With permission from Academic Press,
#UD all the tables from HOCI and a few from HOCII were laser scanned,
#UD and these were added to my original collection from HOCII.   
#UD      Additional new or overlooked papers for the materials in
#UD HOCI and HOCII have been put into a file NEWREFS.WP without
#UD comment.  These may be of interest for updating a table yourself. 
#UD      While the conversion from eV to cm-1 was 8065.48 eV/cm-1 at
#UD the time of HOCI, some of the critiquers used slightly different
#UD values, such as 8065.5 and 8065.  This does not affect experiment
#UD very much, however, because most physicists do not measure
#UD wavelength to four or more figures.  We tried to give the
#UD experimental unit to four or fewer figures and then the other two
#UD units to four figures, so that the reader could spot the units in
#UD which the original experiments had been done.  This is not
#UD obvious in some of the tables where some units are given to five
#UD figures on occasion.  Then translating between the units and
#UD rounding off to four figures can become a problem.  Sometimes, we
#UD have added a significant figure at 1000, 100, 10, 1 eV, etc., in
#UD the adjacent cm-1 column to indicate which conversion factor was
#UD used by the critiquer.
#UD      All cm-1 columns (often left blank above 50000 in HOCI and
#UD HOCII) have been completed, even though it is hard to think in
#UD terms of a number like 12586000 cm-1 (waves per cm). 
#UD      Exponential notation has been filled in for the extinction
#UD coefficient, whereas it was omitted until the exponent changed in
#UD HOCI and HOCII.  While k has been given to as many as four
#UD figures, it is probably no better than two figures at any time.
#UD      While the bulk of the tables in HOCI and HOCII start at high
#UD eV and then descend, occasionally, a table starts at low eV and
#UD rises.  We have sorted these few tables, so that all eV now run
#UD from high to low.  Also, while most of the unit columns are eV,
#UD cm-1, µm in HOCI and HOCII, occasionaly, the cm-1 and µm columns
#UD were reversed.  Now they all have been made consistent.  You may
#UD want to convert to Ångstroms or nanometers in appropriate
#UD spectral regions.
#UD      All the reference brackets in the original tables have been
#UD removed and put into each file heading; footnotes have been
#UD removed completely.  The reference numbers pertinent to each
#UD table (file) are given in the heading of each file.      
#UD      Some of the numbers in the files have been rearranged for
#UD better continuity and to save space.  In overlap regions there
#UD are sometimes large discrepancies between data from different
#UD laboratories.  You will have to read the original text to
#UD discriminate if the original critiquer has not done this for you.
#UD      When two or three different crystal forms of a material were
#UD given in the same table in HOCI and HOCII, e.g., ZnS, we have now
#UD made separate files for ZnS-cubic, ZnS-hexagonal, ZnS-irtran. 
#UD This is especially necessary for the alloy semiconductors PbSnTe,
#UD HgCdTe, AlGaAs as each is really a "different" material.
#UD      The few non-room-temperature values for a few materials in
#UD the original tables have been omitted from the files.
#UD      In some of the files for birefringent materials and
#UD deposited materials, the columns are sometimes interrupted by a
#UD new set of eV, cm-1, µm, n, k columns to list the ordinary and
#UD extraordinary n's and k's or a new set of deposition parameters.  
#UD      Errors and typos in the original tables, found by me or
#UD reported to me by others, have been corrected.
#UD      The index of files presented below lists the file name, the
#UD crystal form of the material, page on which the original table
#UD started in HOCI and HOCII, the left and right margin dimensions,
#UD the Lft (left) or Dec (decimal) tab.  Usually metals,
#UD semiconductors and dielectrics deposited on substrates are
#UD polycrystalline or amorphous in form (except for epitaxy).  Most
#UD metals are cubic but are labeled poly-x, because they were
#UD deposited in some fashion.  Differences in optical constants
#UD between crystalline and polycrystalline material are mostly due
#UD to the deposition process.  Some materials are amorphous.
#UD      While the tables of metals, semiconductors and insulators in
#UD HOCI and HOCII are nominally alphabetized by the name of the
#UD material, the file names are listed by chemical symbol and
#UD alphabetized accordingly.  The files for HOCI are on disk 1,
#UD HOCII on disk 2 and the remainder of HOCII and README.WP,
#UD REFHOCI.WP, REFHOCII.WP and NEWREFS.WP on disk 3.
#UD 
#UD LIST OF MATERIALS:
#UD HOCI

#UREF Hamburg, 1974; "Optical constants from the far infrared to the x-
#UREF ray region: Mg, Al, Cu, Ag, Au, Bi, C, and Al2O3," J. Opt. Soc.
#UREF Am. 65, 742 (1975).

#UREF properties of evaporated gold in the vacuum ultraviolet from 300
#UREF Å to 2000 Å," J. de Physique 25, 124 (1964). 
#UREF 14. B. Dold and R. Mecke, "Über Gangsmetallen und deren
#UREF Leigerungen im Infrarot," Optik 22, 435 (1965). 
#UREF 27. M.L. Theye, "Investigation of the optical properties of Au by
#UREF means of thin semitransparent films," Phys. Rev. B 2, 3060
#UREF (1970). 
#UREF 28. P.O. Nilsson, "Electronic structure of disordered alloys:
#UREF optical and photoemission measurements on Ag-Au and Cu-Au
#UREF alloys," Phys. Kondens. Mater. 11, 1 (1970). 
#UREF 39. H.J. Hagemann, W. Gudat, and C. Kunz, DESY Report SR-74/7,
#UREF Hamburg, 1974; "Optical constants from the far infrared to the x-
#UREF ray region: Mg, Al, Cu, Ag, Au, Bi, C, and Al2O3," J. Opt. Soc.
#UREF Am. 65, 742 (1975).

#UREF Resolution Mirror Assembly Optical System Study," Smithsonian
#UREF Astrophysical Observatory Report SAO-AXAF-80-003, Appendix B.
#UREF Table B1, Cambridge, Massachusetts, (1980).

#UREF -Rh 
#UREF 9. J.T. Cox, G. Hass, and W.R. Hunter, "Optical properties of
#UREF evaporated rhodium films deposited at various substrate
#UREF temperatures in the vacuum ultraviolet from 150 to 2000 Å," J.
#UREF Opt. Soc. Am. 61, 360 (1971). 
#UREF 15. J.H. Weaver, C.G. Olson, and D.W. Lynch, "Optical
#UREF investigation of the electronic structure of bulk Rh and Ir,"
#UREF Phys. Rev. B 15, 4115 (1977). 
#UREF 16. B.L. Henke, P. Lee, T.J. Tanaka, R.L. Shimabukuro, and B.K.
#UREF Fujikawa, "The atomic scattering factor, f1+f2, for 94 elements
#UREF and for the 100 to 2000 eV photon energy region," in Low Energy
#UREF X-Ray Diagnostics - 1981, (D.T. Attwood and B.L. Henke, eds.), p.
#UREF 340, AIP Conf. Proc. No. 75, American Institute of Physics, New

#S 19 KD2PO4 ( tetragonal ammonium dideuterium)
#UO 
#UO KD2PO4.ASC: Values of n for tetragonal ammonium dideuterium
#UO phosphate (KD2PO4) at 33.0 C from various references in HOCII
#UO (pg. 1017).  Reference is 4. 
#UO 	
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO -------------------------------------------------------------
#UO   eV     cm-1      µm     n(o)     n(e) 
#UO -------------------------------------------------------------
#N  5
#L  Energy[eV]  Wavelength[cm-1]  Wavelength[µm]  n(o)  n(e)

#S 13 Al19Ga80 ( cubic aluminum gallium)
#UO 
#UO Al19Ga80.AsA:  Values of n and k for cubic aluminum gallium
#UO arsenide (Al0.198Ga0.802As) from various references in HOCII

#S 13 Al2O3-AP ( amorphous, polycrystalline )
#UO 
#UO Al2O3-AP.ASC: Values of n and k for amorphous, polycrystalline 
#UO or hot-pressed aluminum oxide (99.5 wt% Al2O3) from various

#UO numbers for hot-pressed alumina below 1000 cm-1 are due to C.A.

#S 13 Al41Ga58 ( cubic aluminum gallium)
#UO 
#UO Al41Ga58.AsA:  Values of n and k for cubic aluminum gallium
#UO arsenide (Al0.419Ga0.581As) from various references in HOCII
#UO (pg. 524).  Reference is 2. 
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO -----------------------------------------------------------

#S 13 AlON ( cubic aluminum oxynitride (mostly)
#UO 
#UO AlON.ASC:  Values of n and k for cubic aluminum oxynitride (mostly
#UO 9(Al2O3)5(AlN)) from various references in HOCII (pg. 783). 
#UO References are 2, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 16. 
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.

#S 33 As2Se3-m ( monoclinic arsenic selenide)
#UO 
#UO As2Se3-m.ASC: Values of n and k for monoclinic arsenic selenide
#UO from various references in HOCI (pg. 627). References are 1, 2. 
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1985 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO --------------------------------------------------------------- 
#UO      eV     cm-1    µm      na       nc       ka       kc

#S 4 BeO-h ( hexagonal beryllium oxide )
#UO 
#UO BeO-h.ASC: Values of n and k for hexagonal beryllium oxide from
#UO various references in HOCII (pg. 809).  References are 4, 5, 6. 
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO ------------------------------------------------------------- 
#UO      eV   cm-1   µm      n(o)     k(o)     n(e)     k(e)

#S 6 C-FILM ( amorphous hydrogenated "diamond-)
#UO

#UO like" carbon films (a-C:H) from various references in HOCII (pg.

#UO power, room-temperature substrate, no post-deposition anneal.

#S 20 CaF2 ( cubic calcium fluoride )
#UO 
#UO CaF2.ASC: Values of n and k for cubic calcium fluoride from
#UO various references in HOCII (pg. 830).  References are 41,
#UO 42, 50, 51, 52 53, 88, 89, 90, 91.

#S 48 CdTe ( cubic cadmium telluride )
#UO 
#UO CdTe.ASC: Values of n and k for cubic cadmium telluride from
#UO various references in HOCI (pg. 415).  References are 1, 3, 5, 7,
#UO 8, 9, 10, 11, 14, 15, 17, 18, 21, 22.
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1985 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO ----------------------------------------------------------------
#UO   eV        cm-1       µm      n       n         n       k      k
#UO ----------------------------------------------------------------
#N  8
#L  Energy[eV]  Wavelength[cm-1]  Wavelength[µm]  n  n  n  k  k

#S 31 GaSb ( cubic gallium antimonide )
#UO 
#UO GaSb.ASC: Values of n and k for cubic gallium antimonide from
#UO various references in HOCII (pg. 603).  References are 1, 6, 10. 
#UO 
#UO Copyright (c) 1995 the Optical Society of America.  Contains data
#UO from HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO ----------------------------------------------------------------
#UO  eV     cm-1    µm        n         nc        k 
#UO ----------------------------------------------------------------
#N  6
#L  Energy[eV]  Wavelength[cm-1]  Wavelength[µm]  n  nc  k  
    6.00   48387  0.2067   0.935 -0.0001   2.416

#S 49 InP ( cubic indium phosphide )
#UO 
#UO InP.ASC: Values of n and k for cubic indium phosphide from
#UO various references in HOCI (pg. 508).  References are 1, 3,
#UO 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 15.
#UO 
#UO From HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1985 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO -------------------------------------------------------------

#UO -------------------------------------------------------------
#N  7

#S 11 NaF ( cubic sodium fluoride )
#UO 
#UO NaF.ASC: Values of n and k for cubic sodium fluoride from various
#UO references in HOCII (pg. 1026).  References are 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6,
#UO 7, 9.  At 10 eV we separate the data of refs. 1 (first n, k
#UO columns) and 2 (second n, k columns) to emphasize the large
#UO differences in k.  The sample of ref. 2 was presumably of purer
#UO quality.  At 0.05889 eV we separate the data of refs. 7 and 6
#UO similarly, but it is not obvious why there are factor-of-two
#UO differences in the lattice-vibration region.
#UO 
#UO Copyright (c) 1995 by the Optical Society of America.  Data
#UO from HANDBOOK OF OPTICAL CONSTANTS IN SOLIDS II edited by Edward D.
#UO Palik. Copyright (c) 1991 by Academic Press, Inc. Reproduced by
#UO permission of the publisher.
#UO --------------------------------------------------------------- 
#UO   eV     cm-1       µm       n        k      n        k   
#UO ---------------------------------------------------------------
